00003 sub _PGstatisticsmacros_init {
00004     foreach my $t (@Distributions::EXPORT_OK) {
00005             *{$t} = *{"Distributions::$t"}
00006             }
00007         foreach my $t (@Regression::EXPORT_OK) {
00008                 *{$t} = *{"Regression::$t"}
00009                 }
00010 }
00011 
00012 =head1 Statistics Macros
00013 
00014 =head3 Normal distribution
00015 
00016 =pod
00017 
00018     Usage: normal_prob(a, b, mean=>0, deviation=>1);
00019 
00020 Computes the probability of x being in the interval (a,b) for normal distribution.
00021 The first two arguments are required. Use '-infty' for negative infinity, and 'infty' or '+infty' for positive infinity.
00022 The mean and deviation are optional, and are 0 and 1 respectively by default.
00023 Load PGnumericalmacros.pl in your problem if you use this method.
00024 
00025 =cut
00026 
00027 sub normal_prob {
00028         warn 'You must also load PGnumericalmacros to use PGstatisticsmacros' unless defined(&_PGnumericalmacros_init);
00029 
00030     my $a = shift;
00031         my $b = shift;
00032     my %options=@_;
00033 
00034     my $mean = $options{'mean'} if defined ($options{'mean'});
00035         $mean = 0 unless defined $mean;
00036 
00037     my $deviation = $options{'deviation'} if defined ($options{'deviation'});
00038         $deviation = 1 unless defined $deviation;
00039 
00040     if ($deviation <= 0) {
00041         warn 'Deviation must be a positive number.';
00042         return;
00043         }
00044 
00045         my $z_score_of_a;
00046     my $z_score_of_b;
00047 
00048     if ( $a eq '-infty' ) {
00049         $z_score_of_a = -6;
00050     } else {
00051         $z_score_of_a = ($a - $mean)/$deviation;
00052     }
00053 
00054         if (($b eq 'infty') or ($b eq '+infty')) {
00055         $z_score_of_b = 6;
00056     } else {
00057         $z_score_of_b = ($b - $mean)/$deviation;
00058     }
00059 
00060         my $function = sub { my $x=shift;
00061                              $E**(-$x**2/2)/sqrt(2*$PI);
00062                              };
00063 
00064         my $prob = romberg($function, $z_score_of_a, $z_score_of_b, level => 8);
00065         $prob;
00066 }
00067 
00068 =head3 "Inverse" of normal distribution
00069 
00070 =pod
00071 
00072     Usage: normal_distr(prob, mean=>0, deviation=>1);
00073 
00074 Computes the positive number b such that the probability of x being in the interval (0,b)
00075 is equal to the given probability (first argument). The mean and deviation are
00076 optional, and are 0 and 1 respectively by default.
00077 Caution: since students may use tables, they may only be able to provide the answer correct to 2 or 3
00078 decimal places. Use tolerance when evaluating answers.
00079 Load PGnumericalmacros.pl if you use this method.
00080 
00081 =cut
00082 
00083 sub normal_distr {
00084     warn 'You must also load PGnumericalmacros to use PGstatisticsmacros' unless defined(&_PGnumericalmacros_init);
00085 
00086         my $prob = shift;
00087         my %options=@_;
00088 
00089         my $mean = $options{'mean'} if defined ($options{'mean'});
00090         $mean = 0 unless defined $mean;
00091 
00092         my $deviation = $options{'deviation'} if defined ($options{'deviation'});
00093         $deviation = 1 unless defined $deviation;
00094 
00095         if ($deviation <= 0) {
00096                 warn 'Deviation must be a positive number.';
00097                 return;
00098                 }
00099 
00100         my $function = sub { my $x=shift;
00101                              $E**(-$x**2/2)/sqrt(2*$PI);
00102                              };
00103 
00104         my $z_score_of_b = inv_romberg($function, 0, $prob);
00105 
00106         my $b = $z_score_of_b * $deviation + $mean;
00107         $b;
00108 }
